(52) 80ISth March, 1952CABINETREPORT OF STEEL committee memorandum by the Minister of HealthAt their meeting on 28th December, 1951 (C.C. (51) 20th Conclusions,Minute 5), the Cabinet considered a report which I had circulated on the progress made by the Steel Committee in preparing a plan for returning the iron andsteel industry to private enterprise. The Committee have now completed their work and I present, for the consideration of my colleagues, the attached draft bill which represents their conclusions.2. The Bill repeals the 1949 Act, abolishes the Iron and Steel corporation and transfers its assets and liabilities to a Holding and Realisation Agency, whichwill have the duty of returning the nationalised companies to private ownership.3. Provision is made for the setting up of an Iron and Steel Board to supervise prices, raw materials, major development schemes, research and otherrelated matters.4. All the basic sectors of the iron and steel industry, except the steel founders,are willing to be brought within the ambit of the new Board. The fringe industries(drop forging, springs, nuts and bolts, structural steel, wire rope, wire netting, &c.)have not been included.5. The Committee considered the desirability of providing a guarantee ofcompensation for investors in the event of re-nationalisation. However, in viewof the political storm which this would cause, and of the doubtful effectiveness ofsuch a guarantee, the Committee decided that it would be best not to include this in the Bill. If the attitude of the Opposition in the debates made it desirable,, a clause on these lines could be introduced at the Committee or Report Stage.6. A detailed summary of the main provisions of the Bill is annexed.H. C.Ministry of Health, W. I,ISth March, 1952. " ; annex ,r- \ \, ...... Iron and Steel.Bill . /;,,';V - ' , Summary of Main Provisions r1. The Bill repeals the Iron and Steel Act, 1949, provides for the return to private ownership of iron and steel undertakings at present owned by the Iron andSteel Corporation and arranges for the future supervision of the iron and steelindustry.2. A Holding and Realisation Agency will be established (Clause 22) andall the property, rights, liabilities and obligations of the Iron and Steel corporation will be transferred to it (Clause 1).3. The Corporation will cease to exist on a date to be appointed by theGovernment after the passing of the Act (Clause 1).4. An Iron and Steel Board consisting of seven to eleven members and anindependent Chairman will be established. It will have the duty of supervisingmajor development schemes, raw materials, prices, research and arrangements for workers' safety, health and welfare (Clause 3).5. The sections of the industry which will come under the aegis of the board are set out in the Third Schedule and can be summarised as follows: (i) Iron ore working.(ii) The production of iron and steel by any process.(iii) Iron and steel founding.(iv) The rolling, drawing, extrusion or forging (excluding hand and dropforging) of iron and steel and tube manufacture (other than cold drawntubes).(v) The manufacture of tinplate and terneplate (Clause 4).6. The Board will have the duty of consulting the industry with a view to securing desirable developments (Clause 5).7. If the Board think that additional facilities should be provided and cannotpersuade the industry to do so, they are to inform the Minister of Supply, who mayarrange their provision at Government expense (Clause 6).8. Iron and Steel firms will have to seek the Board's consent before carryingout major development schemes. If the Board's consent is withheld, the firms mayappeal to the Minister of Supply (Clause 7).9. The Board, like the former Corporation, are to consult with other bodies concerned (e.g., the National Coal Board) about carbonisation schemes (Clause 8).10. All iron and steel producers must observe any maximum prices laid downby the Board (Clause 9). II they do not, the Board can seek an injunction against them (Clause 40). The Minister of Supply will be able, by Statutory Order, to direct the Board to vary prices they have laid down or to lay down prices where they have failed to do so. The Board are not to fix a price for any product while its price is controlled by the Minister under Defence Regulations. The Minister is to consult the Board before making any iron and steel scrap price Orders under defence regulations (Clause 10).11. If the Board think that existing arrangements for importing and distribu-ting raw materials are not adequate, they may arrange for it to be carried out asa common service (Clause 11).12. If the Board or the Minister of Supply think that supplies of home-pro-duced iron or steel are inadequate, the Board are to arrange imports of finishediron or steel (Clause 12). With the Minister^ consent, imported raw materials and finished products may be sold at a loss (Clause 13).13. If the existing arrangements are inadequate, the Board may promoteresearch, and training and education, connected with iron and steel production,and may make grants and loans for these purposes (Clause .14).14. The Board must give the Minister any information he needs and haveto arrange the publication of statistics concerning iron and steel. They are to make an annual report to the Minister of Supply which he is to lay before Parliament(Clause 15). 15. Every firm engaged in the iron and steel industry is to supply the board with any information reasonably required and must provide facilities for itsverification (Clause 16).16. The Board may have delegated to them any functions of the Ministerof Supply affecting iron and steel, except those given to him by this Bill or thepower to make Orders (Clause 17).17. The Board will prepare a scheme for the industry to pay levies to financeits expenditure. The scheme will be published and it will not come into operation now it has been confirmed by the Minister of Supply (Clause 18).18. The Board may borrow money temporarily and may invest surplus money,but not in the steel industry. The Treasury may guarantee temporary borrowingup to 1 million (Clause 19).19. The Board are to keep proper accounts and have them audited. their statement of accounts together with the Auditors' report shall be published ormade available for inspection (Clause 20).20. While any companies remain in public ownership, they are to be in thesame position as privately-owned companies vis-a-vis the Board and the Ministerof Supply (Clause 21).21. The Agency have the duty of returning the publicly-owned companies to private ownership. They may sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of their under -takings or any part of them. They are to have the normal powers of a share-holder and may bring about mergers, reorganisations and capital reconstructions.The Agency's powers are to be exercised with the consent of the appropriate department (normally the Treasury) which may give directions to them at anytime. The Agency are to consult the Board before carrying out any re-groupings(Clauses 23 and 24).22. The Agency may, with the consent of the Treasury, lend money to andguarantee the debts of the companies in which they hold securities (Clause 25).23. The Treasury are to take over liability for British Iron and Steel Stockwhich is to be re-named " 3^ per cent. Treasury Stock 1979-81 "; its terms willnot be changed (Clause 26).24. The Treasury may make advances to the Agency up to a limit of 150 million (Clause 27).25. Any excess revenue of the Agency is to be paid into the Exchequer(Clause 28).26. Any other surplus monies are to be paid into an Iron and Steel RealisationAccount to be kept by the Treasury, who are to transmit to the Comptroller and auditor-General an account of payments to and receipts from the account(Clause 30).27. The Treasury will appoint the Agency's Auditors and will lay beforeParliament a statement of the Agency's accounts and the Auditors' report(Clause 31).28. The Agency are to make an annual report which will be laid beforeParliament (Clause 33).29. The Treasury may dissolve the Agency when they consider its objectshave been substantially accomplished and take over its assets and liabilities(Clause 34).30. Except where specially provided, powers of other Ministers and Depart-ments are not affected by the Bill (Clause 41). Neither the Board nor the Agencywill be a servant of the Crown or a public authority for the purposes of the public authorities Protection Act (1893) and the Limitation Act (1939).31. The First Schedule contains transitional provisions covering the transferof assets from the Corporation to the Agency.32. The Second Schedule regulates the internal procedure of the Board andthe Agency.33. The Third Schedule defines the sectors of the industry to come withintheasgis of the Board (see paragraph 5 above).
